articles.title: Jason Matthews 'disgusted' by actions of anti-racism protestors
articles.author: Jason Matthews
articles.summary: 4BC Mornings host Jason Matthews is disgusted by the actions of the anti-racism protestors who burned the Australian flag and were violent towards police officers. Matthews supports the March for Australia and is sick of seeing people damaging our Australian flag under the banner of protest.

articles.title: Indonesia Prepares Banten's Coastal Communities For Quakes And Tsunamis
articles.author: Malaysian National News Agency
articles.summary: Indonesia is stepping up disaster preparedness in Pandeglang regency, one of Banten Province's most hazard-prone areas, as experts warn.    .   i   in this article we reported that Indonesia is preparing Bantsen's Coastal Communities for Quakes and Tsunamis.

articles.title: Some scientists challenge logic of Victoria's fuel reduction burns
articles.author: Madeleine Stuchbery
articles.summary: A dry winter in regional Victoria has presented opportunities for fuel load reduction burns. Forest Fire Management Victoria treated nearly 4,000 hectares of public lands across 81 different planned burns. Ecologists and environmentalists are challenging the planned burns methodology. Professor David Lindenmayer has published more than 1,442 scientific works, and is an expert in forest ecology and resource management. Karl Just has conducted over 1,000 fuel hazard assessments.

articles.title: Aussies brace for week of record-breaking weather chaos: 'Extreme danger'
articles.author: Joe Attanasio
articles.summary: Record-breaking heat is set to scorch the east of Australia, while the south braces for storms, downpours and damaging winds. Much of the nation's interior is already sweltering, with temperatures sizzling over 15 degrees above average in some regions. The combination of heat and wind is also triggering heightened fire risks.

articles.title: Record Flu Cases This Year Prompt Vaccination Warning
articles.author: SBS News
articles.summary: There have been over 410,000 lab-confirmed cases of influenza in 2025 according to the Royal Australian College of GPs. This is an increase of nearly 11 per cent from last year, and 13,000 cases have been confirmed in October alone. There were also the lowest vaccination rates in five years.

articles.title: Ottawa Fire Services announces burn ban for city
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: A burn ban is now in effect for Ottawa. All open-air fires are prohibited, except on properties with an open air fire permit. The ban applies to agricultural burns, brush pile burns and campfires. There will be zero tolerance enforcement during the fire ban.

articles.title: We Can't Stop Climate Change, So We Need to Prepare for It â€“ The Wall Street Journal
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Opinion: We can't stop climate change, so we need to prepare for it. The Wall Street Journal has published the opinion piece. The article is based on an article by William Bennett, which is published in the WSJ's online edition.

articles.title: Smallholder Farmers in Africa: Climate Strategies Reviewed
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Mosha and Ngulube conducted a systematic review of climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies among smallholder farmers in Africa. The review highlights the urgent need for farmers to adopt innovative practices that can sustain their livelihoods in the face of environmental uncertainty. The authors argue that government support can play a critical role in providing the necessary resources and educational training for farmers. They also stress the importance of community engagement and knowledge-sharing.

articles.title: Ottawa breaks fall heat record with 26 C day
articles.author: Adam Beauchemin
articles.summary: Temperatures hit 25.9 C on Sunday in Ottawa, a new high for this time of the year. Environment Canada's forecast calls for a high of 26 C and a low of 13 C today. Showers are expected to begin after midnight. The average high temperature for October is around 13 C.

articles.title: World's carbon dioxide levels hit a record high in 2024: Report
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the atmosphere soared by a record amount to new highs in 2024, committing the planet to more long-term temperature increase, according to a new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). WMO recommends expanding and sustaining greenhouse gas monitoring.

articles.title: Caribbean's poor face growing climate threat
articles.summary: Caribbean nations continue to grapple with deep inequalities and rising climate risks, according to the Global Multidimensional Poverty Index 2025 released by UNDP and Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative. Haiti continues to record some of the highest poverty levels globally, with more than 40 per cent of its population considered multidimensionally poor.

articles.title: Major Alaska storm damage could displace thousands for 18 months, governor warm
articles.author: Karissa Waddick
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong hit Alaska's western coast last weekend, destroying the area's infrastructure and pushing homes off their foundations. Alaska's emergency management agency estimated that 90% of structures in Kipnuk were lost in the storm and a third were destroyed in Kwingillingok. The Alaska National Guard airlifted more than 600 people out of the battered region to Bethel, the largest city in western Alaska.

articles.title: When is bushfire fuel at its driest and why it is later than you think?
articles.author: Gregor Heard
articles.summary: The meteorological data regarding the driest air was as expected, with a peak time around 3pm in the afternoon. However, there was a previously undocumented finding regarding the fuel load and its peak dryness, according to ANU researcher Nick Wilson.

articles.title: Agriculture, garments at risk sans Philippine-EU FTA
articles.author: The Philippine Star
articles.summary: The agriculture and garment sectors stand to be the most affected if the Philippines is unable to cope with climate change.   Â   Ã‚   in the agriculture and garments sectors. The country's economy will be affected if it does not meet climate change targets.

articles.title: Climate Change is Spiraling Out of Control
articles.author: Alan Singer
articles.summary: According to the Copernicus Climate Change Service of the European Union, 2024 was the hottest year on record. The previous hottest year was 2023. The average level of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere climbed by the highest amount ever between 2023 and 2024 because of the burning of fossil fuels. Global warming will soon exceed 1.5Â°C. There are multiple climate tipping points that pose catastrophic risks to billions of people.

articles.title: UN relentlessly propagates fear about man-made climate change to grasp control
articles.author: Rhoda
articles.summary: The UN's weather and climate agency, the World Meteorological Organisation, has recently claimed that atmospheric CO2 was up by a 'record amount' in 2024. This is not true. Recently, the CO2 levels have declined to near extinction of life levels. The UN is a power-hungry behemoth, relentlessly propagating fear.

articles.title: Climate-safe features vital in resilient housing
articles.author: Erika Mioten
articles.summary: As the frequency and intensity of climate-related disasters increase, the concept of resilient housing has emerged as a critical priority for communities in the Philippines. More than 60 million Filipinos are expected to move from their current homes by 2100 due to the projected one-meter sea level rise caused by climate change. 56 projects are in various stages of development under the 4PH program.

articles.title: Top 10 U.S. Cities in Delaware Most Affected by Climate Change
articles.author: Climate Cosmos Team
articles.summary: Wilmington, Delaware's largest city, is particularly vulnerable to flooding due to climate change. Lewes is experiencing the relentless encroachment of rising seas. Rehoboth Beach is vulnerable to sea-level rise and coastal erosion. Delaware's capital, Dover, is experiencing increased temperatures and more frequent intense storms. Newark's academic community is exploring ways to focus on sustainability.

articles.title: Letters: Every day they are on strike is a day of unprofessionalism; rapid climate change is man-made
articles.author: NZ Herald
articles.summary: Hylton Le Grice's letter about climate change is wrong. Fonterra's decision to sell Anchor butter and Mainland cheese is gutless and uninspired. Mayor Brown's focus on Auckland's transport needs should include street-level servicing of public transport routes.

articles.title: To fight â€˜eco-paralysis' we must first understand the mindset
articles.author: Jamie Morton
articles.summary: Dr Niki HarrÃ© is a psychology professor at Waipapa Taumata Rau University of Auckland's School of Psychology. Her research has explored the power of storytelling in fostering greater action and awareness on environmental issues. She believes people are hard-wired to deal with abstract threats that don't feel immediate, but big, scary numbers can be powerful motivators if framed in the right way.

articles.title: NASA supercomputer made terrifying prediction for when the world will end
articles.author: Anish Vij
articles.summary: Scientists from Toho University in Japan and NASA used supercomputers to predict when the Earth will end. Life on Earth is tied directly to the lifespan and evolution of the Sun. The Sun will continue to expand and emit more heat, transforming Earth into an increasingly hostile environment. Earth will become unlivable in 1,000,002,021.

articles.title: COE issues alert due to deteriorating maritime conditions along the country's coasts
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: The Emergency Operations Center (COE) has issued an alert due to the progressive deterioration of maritime conditions on both coasts of the Dominican Republic. Small and medium-sized vessel operators are advised to remain in port from Cabo EngaÃ±o (La Altagracia) to Miches (El Seibo). For the rest of the coast, it is advisable to sail close to the coastal perimeter and avoid venturing offshore.

articles.title: Perspective: Hurricanes, the Calusa and What We Can Learn
articles.author: David Outerbridge
articles.summary: The Southwest Coast of Florida is a hurricane hotspot between June and November each year. The Calusa lived there for nearly 2,000 years. Their success was due to their deep environmental knowledge, innovative land and seascape infrastructure, and cultivation of social capital within and between communities.

articles.title: The sixth extinction? How humans are driving species to the edge of survival
articles.author: Knowridge
articles.summary: Today's loss of species is extraordinary, but it has not yet reached the catastrophic levels of a true 'mass extinction'. If biodiversity continues to decline at the current pace, we could soon cross that line. Human activity may be setting the stage for the largest extinction event since the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs 66 million years ago, according to a new scientific review.

articles.title: Showing of new movie by Abby Martin â€“ Earth's Greatest Enemy
articles.summary: The documentary Earth's Greatest Enemy details the damage inflicted on the global environment by the U.S. military. Short introductory comments on the links between militarism and climate change will be presented by Veterans For Peace volunteers who are participating in the Wake Up to Climate Crisis and NO MAS (NO Military Air Shows) Tour.

articles.title: Destruction continues as 11th Outer Banks home falls into ocean, NC park says
articles.author: Mark Price
articles.summary: Houses are falling at a record rate on North Carolina's Outer Banks. The 11th house collapsed overnight on Saturday, Oct. 18, at 46006 Cottage Avenue in Buxton. It is the fourth to fall since September 30. 22 homes have collapsed in the area since 2020. Coast erosion and sea level rise are the cause.

articles.title: Global Warming Claims Crumble As Data Challenges Media Hysteria
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: Global warming hysteria has been cooling off, but it's not cold-on-the-slab, yet.    .   i.e. the weather is not getting warmer. It's not getting colder on the slab either, but not as hot.

articles.title: New Study Contradicts The Alarmist Narrative That Says the AMOC Is Catastrophically Collapsing
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: Alarmists claim that the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is on the verge of collapse due to anthropogenic climate change. Sea level rise from New York to France has been stable, not accelerating, since 1960. This confirms the stability of the AMOC and contradicts the narrative that it's weakening.

articles.title: IUCN: Nearly half of World Heritage sites face climate change
articles.author: leila yazdani
articles.summary: IUCN's World Heritage Outlook 4 report evaluated 271 World Heritage sites designated by UNESCO for their natural and cultural significance. It found that about 43% of them face high or very high threat from climate change. The figure represents a sharp increase compared to 2020, when 33% of sites were at risk, and 2017, when the rate was 27%.

articles.title: Wildfires still burning on Vancouver Island amid serious drought
articles.summary: There were six wildfires burning on Vancouver Island this past week. The Coastal Fire Centre has had 226 fires since the fire season started on April 1. In 2024, there were 157 fires in the centre and 52 on the Island. The current fire season had a campfire ban from July 17 to Oct. 3.

articles.title: POWER OF YES: Can we talk?
articles.author: Teresa Ganna Porter
articles.summary: Climate Action Newmarket-Aurora has begun interacting with community groups to talk about climate change and hosted a market tent at both Newmarket and Aurora farmers markets in September. They asked people to choose their fears and hopes about the climate change from among a number of options. Wildfire, drought and extreme heat topped the list of climate fears, while leading causes for hope were solar energy, scientists and local progress.

articles.title: Dispatches From the Winter of Our Discontent Against Woodside Energy's Carbon Bomb
articles.author: Fiona Carberry
articles.summary: This year was a year of change for many people in Australia. The environment minister's decision to keep burning gas until 2070 at the North West Shelf (NWS) plant on the Burrup Peninsula in WA is a climate change issue. Woodside Energy is Australia and WA's second worst fossil fuels polluter, headed by American 'Methane Meg' O'Neill, formerly of ExxonMobil.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu Rain Alert: Low Pressure System Triggers Coastal Downpours
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: A low-pressure system lies over the South Andaman Sea and its surrounding southeast Bay of Bengal. It is expected to intensify into a well-marked low- pressure area by October 21 and move west-northwestward. Light to moderate rainfall accompanied by thunder and lightning is likely in several parts of Tamil Nadu, Puducherry, and Karaikal on Sunday. Heavy rain is also expected in one or two places, particularly in the hilly regions of Coimbatore district, and in The Nilgiris, Erode, Tiruppur, Theni, Tenkasi, Tirunelveli, and Kanniyakumari districts.

articles.title: Letter: Administration plays perilous climate game
articles.summary: Ursula Eisenpress is concerned about climate change. Donald Trump wants people to ignore it, but Ursula and others know it's a terrible reality. The Honolulu Star-Advertiser welcomes all opinions and welcomes letters up to 150 words.   It reserves the right to edit for clarity and length.

articles.title: Is daylight saving time going away? Fall 2025 time change is approaching
articles.author: Alexis Simmerman
articles.summary: The time change is two weeks away. The 48 states that observe daylight saving time will get an extra hour of sleep. Arizona and Hawaii are the only U.S. states that have never changed their clocks for the practice. The Navajo Nation hasn't either. The territories of American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands and Puerto Rico don't observe it.

articles.title: Australian National Review - â€˜Global Left' versus â€˜Global Right' â€“ a Divide and Conquer Strategy?
articles.author: Cairns News
articles.summary: The March for Australia in Melbourne brought out the predictable rabble of leftist supporters of mass immigration. They ranted about 'fascists', 'Nazis' and 'racists'. They waved red and black Antifa and Palestinian flags. Antifa has been declared a terrorist organisation in the US.

articles.title: [Opinion] 2025 SkS Weekly Climate Change & Global Warming News Roundup #42
articles.author: Skeptical Science
articles.summary: A listing of 27 news and opinion articles we found interesting and shared on social media during the past week: Sun, October 12, 2025 thru Sat, October 18, 2025. This week, we promoted 6 articles, by category: Climate Change Impacts (6 articles).

articles.title: Climate crisis demands collective action, says VC Gomal University
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Prof. Zafar Iqbal, Vice Chancellor Gomal University, has said that the growing climate crisis poses a more serious threat to humanity than terrorism and requires urgent, collective action from all segments of society. Dera Ismail Khan, (UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 19th Oct, 2025)

articles.title: End Of The World?' 'Earth's Life Support Is Failing. Will We Act?'
articles.author: Alicia Lutz
articles.summary: The military industrial complex and their controllers feel they have the right to play God with the weather. The latest installment of Global Alert News is below. The title of Marjorie Taylor Greene's upcoming governmental hearing to address the climate engineering atrocities taking place in the skies is: 'Playing God With the Weather â€” a Disastrous Forecast'.

articles.title: Aussies face brutal heatwave this summer
articles.author: Cameron Micallef
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology's long-range forecast predicts a hot summer for most parts of Australia. There is a 60 to 80 per cent chance that maximum temperatures across Australia will be above average. The only part of the country likely to avoid this extreme weather is the NSW coastline. Sky News weather meteorologist Tamsin Green predicts the hottest October week in nearly two decades.

articles.title: 16th Region boys soccer championship: Changing the game: Russell comes out on top of back-and-forth match with Boyd
articles.summary: This time of year often brings about change. The leaves change, the temperatures change and soon even the time will change. It's a changing time of the year for Grayson. It is also a time of change for everyone else. It can be a good time for change.

articles.title: 16th Region girls soccer final: Making new memories: Barker's hat trick, late penalty kick sends Red Devils to region title
articles.summary: This time of year often brings about change. The leaves change, the temperatures change, and pretty soon even the time will change too.   GRAYSON is a writer and photographer based in Grayson, Arizona. He has written several books and has directed a TV series.

articles.title: 16th Region girls soccer championship: Changing the game: Russell comes out on top of back-and-forth match with Boyd
articles.summary: This time of year often brings about change. The leaves change, the temperatures change and soon even the time will change. It's a changing time of the year for Grayson. It is also a time of change for everyone else. It can be a good time for change.

articles.title: Can Jamaica withstand a Hurricane Gilbert 2.0?
articles.summary: The September 19 flooding in Jamaica's capital, Kingston, was a reminder that the island is grappling with a problem that is deepening every year. This event occurred 37 years and seven days after Hurricane Gilbert made landfall near Kingston, at around 1 p.m. It was estimated that the cost of the flood was probably over a billion dollars. Climate change means a drastic change in the frequency and intensity of rainfall and hurricane events. Jamaica is one of the world's most exposed countries to natural hazards.

articles.title: How Oxfordshire residents can protect against flooding
articles.author: Jacob Manuschka
articles.summary: Environment Agency is warning people about the risk of flooding during its annual Flood Action Week campaign. The agency urges people to prepare by knowing their flood risk, making a plan, and signing up for warnings. Flood Re is also urging people to check their risk and take action to prepare for it.

articles.title: Over 22,000 evacuated due to tropical storm Ramil, Philippines
articles.author: Qna Manila
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Ramil brought heavy rains and strong winds to Luzon Island. 22,311 people were evacuated from Calabarzon and Bicol. At least 39 seaports were damaged, stranding 3,242 passengers and 1,050 cargo vessels.

articles.title: Going where the wind blows
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: Samantha Connor is conducting research on sheep in the South Australia arid zone. She wants to better understand how to manage and improve grazing and make informed decisions about infrastructure such as watering points. Ms Connor wants to connect farmers and industries and make sure everyone's working together.

articles.title: Rising temperatures are threatening UK trees - but these species could save our forests
articles.author: Simon King
articles.summary: Some of the UK's most valued trees are struggling to keep pace with climate change and increasing extreme weather. Forestry England has created a 'species for the future' list highlighting 30 trees likely to thrive in a warmer climate. The aim is to create stronger, more diverse forests that can adapt to the changing climate.

articles.title: Kerala drenched: Rivers rise, hills shiver as orange alert looms
articles.author: Nh Digital
articles.summary: Idukki, a hill district in Kerala, is the epicentre of flooding and mudslides. Several families have been moved to relief camps. The Mullaperiyar dam recorded a steady rise in water levels, prompting the Tamil Nadu Water Resources Department to open 13 spillway shutters by 100 cm.

articles.title: El NiÃ±o and La NiÃ±a Affect Eye Health Too, Not Just Weather
articles.author: Managed Healthcare Executive
articles.summary: El NiÃ±o and La NiÃ±a weather patterns can worsen eye conditions such as dry eye, cataracts, infections, and UV-related damage. They can also influence disease outbreaks and access to care. Andrew G. Lee, M.D., explained this at the American Academy of Ophthalmology meeting.

articles.title: Brutal summer ahead: Bureau warns of record heat across Australia
articles.author: Cameron Micallef
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology's long-range forecast predicts a hot summer for most parts of Australia. There is a 60 to 80 per cent chance that maximum temperatures across Australia will be above average. The only part of the country likely to avoid this extreme weather is the NSW coastline. Sky News weather meteorologist Tamsin Green predicts the hottest October week in nearly two decades.

articles.title: Brutal summer forecast: BOM warns of record-breaking temps ahead
articles.author: Cameron Micallef
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology's long-range forecast predicts a hot summer for most parts of Australia. There is a 60 to 80 per cent chance that maximum temperatures will be above average. There's a 50/50 chance of higher temperatures in Victoria, Tasmania and the Pilbara, and a greater chance in central Victoria and Tasmania. The middle of each state is tipped to swelter. The only part of the country likely to avoid this extreme weather is the NSW coastline, thanks to extra moisture after a very wet winter moderating the daytime heat. Sea temperatures in Australia are also likely to remain elevated.

articles.title: Thousands flee Philippine coast as storm approaches
articles.author: Juiceapac Web Development Team
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Fengshen is forecast to hit Catanduanes island late Saturday with gusts of up to 90 km/h. A second landfall is expected on the main island of Luzon on Sunday morning. Nearly 17,000 residents of Albay and more than 9,000 in Catanduans moved to safer ground.

articles.title: Another beachfront home in Buxton collapses Saturday night
articles.author: Wral Staff
articles.summary: Another Buxton home along the North Carolina coast collapsed on Saturday night. This comes as nine other homes collapsed earlier this month due to dangerous surf conditions caused by Hurricane Imelda. The Cape Hatteras National Seashore issued a public safety alert earlier this week.

articles.title: Global CO2 levels reach highest ever, sparking WMO climate warning
articles.author: Anabelle Colaco
articles.summary: The level of carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere has reached its highest point in recorded history, according to the World Meteorological Organization. The report comes weeks before the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Brazil. The rise is driven by the continued burning of fossil fuels and a spike in wildfires, particularly across South America.

articles.title: Bahrain News: Study puts new focus on sustainability of buildings
articles.author: Melissa Nazareth
articles.summary: BAHRAIN is among the countries with the highest energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions per capita. The reports attribute the pattern to extremely high summer temperatures, poorly designed buildings, significant reliance on fossil fuels for energy production, severe water scarcity and the expansion of buildings due to population growth.

articles.title: â€˜Philippine economy must brace for political unrest, natural disasters'
articles.author: Bella Cariaso
articles.summary: Philippine economy must prepare for potential disruptions from political instability and intensifying natural hazards that could undermine growth. Corruption, red tape and bureaucratic inefficiencies continue to discourage both local and foreign investments. The Philippines is one of the most disaster-prone countries in the world.

articles.title: Lessons from 19th century N.S. crop failure resonate in age of climate change
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: A potato blight caused hardship for rural communities in 1845. Today, climate change is creating new threats, but there are lessons to be learned from the past, as well as lessons from the current climate change situation. The lessons can be learned by looking back to the past.

articles.title: Aussie Climate Agency Admits Not Checking Data in Major Climate Risk Report
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: The Australian Climate Service says it did not change the climate.    The ACS did not alter the climate according to the ACS, as it claims. It is not clear whether it did or did not. It's not clear if it changed at all.

articles.title: Slashing methane emissions is the climate's emergency brake
articles.author: Sun Sentinel
articles.summary: Methane levels in the atmosphere are rising at a record pace despite pledges by 159 countries to cut methane emissions by 30% by 2030. Daphne Wysham is concerned about the warming risks of carbon dioxide in the air after this summer's brutally hot summer.

articles.title: New Data Shows Record CO2 Levels in 2024. Are Carbon Sinks Failing?
articles.author: Slashdot
articles.summary: There was a record rise in CO2 in 2024 despite a pledge by the world's countries in 2023 to reduce fossil fuel use in the atmosphere. The rise is due to the continued burning of fossil fuels.   Â    "The Guardian" reports that atmospheric carbon dioxide soared by a record amount in 2024.

articles.title: Melting ice temporarily protects Antarctica's ocean against carbon disaster: Study
articles.author: Interesting Engineering
articles.summary: A new study challenges previous climate predictions. It shows that climate change has impacted the Southern Ocean's ability to absorb carbon dioxide. The water that upwells from the depths of the ocean is very old and cannot be affected by climate change, according to scientists from the Alfred Wegener Institute.
